node.statement: (Synthesis: Exponential integrability for all k=1,2,3) Combining the three cases: (1) For k=1, E_mu[exp(alpha <f, :phi:>)] = E_mu[exp(alpha <f, phi>)] < infinity for all alpha in R, by sub-Gaussian tails of mu (node 1.6.2.1). (2) For k=2, E_mu[exp(alpha <f, :phi^2:>)] < infinity for all alpha in R, by quartic domination at the regularized level and Fatou's lemma in the limit (node 1.6.2.2). (3) For k=3, E_mu[exp(alpha <f, :phi^3:>)] < infinity for all alpha in R, by the same quartic-domination strategy with Young's inequality (node 1.6.2.3). This establishes the claim of node 1.6.2 in full. Note: The key mechanism for k=2,3 is that the quartic interaction -lambda integral phi^4 dx in the Phi^4_3 density provides super-quadratic and super-cubic decay, so that any polynomial perturbation of degree <= 3 can be absorbed into the quartic potential via Young's inequality. The passage from regularized to limiting measure uses the L^p convergence of Wick powers (node 1.6.1) and Fatou's lemma. QED.
